claim: Sitting close to the television can cause eyestrain.

supporting.text: Prolonged focus on a nearby screen can lead to eye muscle fatigue, contributing to eyestrain.

attacks.text: Prolonged focus on a nearby screen can lead to eye muscle fatigue, contributing to eyestrain.
Modern screens emit less harmful light and have features like blue light filters, reducing the risk of eyestrain.
Even with modern screens, prolonged close viewing still forces the eyes to converge and accommodate excessively.
Eyestrain is primarily caused by lack of blinking and dry eyes, not screen proximity.
Close screen viewing increases accommodative demand, which is a documented cause of eye fatigue.
Individual differences in eye health and viewing habits make generalized claims about screen distance unreliable.

supporting.text: Sitting too close to a television may reduce blinking frequency, causing dry eyes and discomfort.

attacks.text: Sitting too close to a television may reduce blinking frequency, causing dry eyes and discomfort.
Modern televisions emit less harmful light and have features like blue light filters, reducing the risk of eyestrain from proximity.
Even with modern features, prolonged close viewing can still strain eye muscles due to fixed focal distance.
Studies show blinking frequency varies widely among individuals, making the link between TV proximity and dry eyes inconsistent.
Controlled experiments demonstrate reduced blinking during screen use regardless of individual variability.

supporting.text: Modern televisions emit blue light, which at close range can increase visual stress and eyestrain.

attacks.text: Modern televisions emit blue light, which at close range can increase visual stress and eyestrain.
Most modern TVs have built-in blue light filters or eye-care modes that significantly reduce the risk of eyestrain.
Blue light filters are not always enabled by default, and many users are unaware of their existence or benefits.
Eyestrain from close TV viewing is more likely due to prolonged focus rather than blue light exposure alone.
Blue light has been shown to disrupt circadian rhythms and cause eye fatigue independent of focus duration.

supporting.text: Viewing a screen from an improper distance may force the eyes to work harder to maintain focus, leading to strain.

attacks.text: Viewing a screen from an improper distance may force the eyes to work harder to maintain focus, leading to strain.
Modern screens (LED/LCD) emit less harmful light and have automatic brightness adjustments, reducing the risk of eyestrain regardless of distance.
Even with modern screens, prolonged focus at a fixed distance can still cause ciliary muscle fatigue, contributing to eyestrain.
Eyestrain is more strongly linked to screen time duration than viewing distance, making distance a minor factor.
Close viewing distance exacerbates the effects of prolonged screen time by increasing the angular size of the screen, forcing more intense focus.

supporting.text: The American Academy of Ophthalmology states that sitting close to screens does not cause permanent eye damage but can result in temporary eyestrain.

attacks.text: The American Academy of Ophthalmology states that sitting close to screens does not cause permanent eye damage but can result in temporary eyestrain.
Studies show that prolonged screen time, regardless of distance, is the primary cause of eyestrain, not proximity alone.
The American Academy of Ophthalmology's statement is based on general cases and may not account for individuals with pre-existing eye conditions.
Children often sit closer to screens due to their shorter focal length, but research indicates no significant difference in eyestrain compared to adults.
Children's developing eyes may be more susceptible to strain from close screen proximity, even if temporary.
